151397150.review:
damn near 10/10

pros:
-good pacing, amazing characters, very rewarding storylines, good cliffhangers at the end of each chapter, amazing character arcs, great backstories and setup for future games, and great substories.
-ending of the game was literally perfect
-combat is actually pretty good and really easy to understand, even if it does get a bit braindead and repetitive at times. 
-fighting styles are (mostly) amazing. brawler and thug are both pretty great all-around styles, rush is fun, beast and slugger are always a blast, and breaker is uh... breaker: fun style but rarely used it. legend styles were alright, i liked that they kept some of the passives from the other styles but they felt very one note compared to the already fully fleshed out styles the game had.
-minigames are good for the most part: the vincent games are pretty great, the sega arcade games are okay, the gambling games at west park range from utterly confusing (all the hanafuda games) to great (all the dice games), the batting center is good, bowling is good, karaoke is great, and fishing is kinda just there but it's not bad. 
-pocket circuit is amazing.
-real estate royale was a great business. very simple and didn't need very much interaction like cabaret club czar did. kinda got boring after a little while, though. storyline was pretty decent.
-cabaret club czar was a great business as well, being even more interactive than real estate. liked the customization a lot and the fact that you get to make the roster to your liking. storyline was also decent.
-so amon was a good fight.

cons:
-maharaja. i hate disco with a passion. it had not one hard substory line, not two hard substory lines, but THREE SEPERATE HARD SUBSTORY LINES.
-catfights. rng bullshit, and not even a great way to make money since mr shakedown exists. visited probably once or twice and then never again
-mahjong. didn't even bother with it. same with shogi.
-telephone club. not an awful minigame by any stretch of the imagination, but the substories ruined it by making you pay attention to every little detail to figure out which girl you were matching with. some of the voices literally sounded identical and you would get a dupe of a date. good minigame, bad rng.
-didn't even know the casino existed until i looked it up. could be good but putting it as a con since i never knew it was there.
-real estate royale got very stale and almost felt like it didn't exist due to making so much money off of shakedown. nothing really kept me coming back after i beat the storyline.
-cabaret club czar felt like an absolute drag when the storyline was complete, and it was especially agonizing trying to get through every training and date with the platinum hostesses. it got to the point where i just ran an all bronze cast and went afk to let the time pass to let me do another date. i also didn't win any date that wasn't disco or karaoke :(.
-no mention of yumi like whatsoever.
-jo amon was a bad fight.

overall:
9.7/10
amazing game, highly recommend

🌆 Streets Alive with Nostalgia:
Yakuza 0 isn't just a game; it's a captivating journey through the electric streets of 1980s Japan. The nostalgia hits like a warm hug, making every neon-soaked alley feel like a portal to a bygone era.

🕶️ Kiryu and Majima: Your New Best Mates:
In the world of Yakuza 0, Kiryu and Majima aren't mere characters; they're your companions through a gripping narrative that unfolds like a classic novel. Kiryu's stoicism and Majima's unpredictable antics create a duo that's so real, you'll find yourself invested in their stories as if they were your own friends.

🍜 Substories: Quirky Tales of Friendship:
Venturing into substories is like stumbling upon hidden gems within the main narrative. From boosting a dominatrix's confidence to aiding a lost street performer, these quirky tales add layers of charm, turning Yakuza 0 into an experience that transcends gaming and feels like a collection of heartfelt short stories.

🎮 Combat Choreography, Virtuoso Style:
The beatdowns in Yakuza 0 aren't just fights; they're symphonies of combat. Kiryu and Majima dance through different styles with an elegance that mirrors a ballet performance. It's not just about brawling; it's about orchestrating a masterpiece with every punch and kick.

🎶 Retro Vibes, Disco Dreams:
Immerse yourself in the '80s soundtrack that is nothing short of an auditory masterpiece. Whether you're witnessing Kiryu's dance moves or managing a cabaret club, the blend of retro tunes and immersive activities creates an award-winning experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming.

👔 Entrepreneurial Escapades and Endearing Eccentricities:
Yakuza 0 isn't afraid to veer into uncharted territory with side businesses. Managing real estate or running a cabaret club? It's an unexpected twist that adds a layer of authenticity, making you feel like you're not just playing a game but navigating the intricacies of life alongside Kiryu and Majima.

🎉 The Verdict: An Award-Worthy Masterpiece:
Yakuza 0 isn't just a game; it's an award-winning testament to storytelling, friendship, and the magic of the '80s. The characters are more than pixels; they're friends you laugh with, cry for, and root for. It's not just a game; it's an experience that deserves to be celebrated and remembered.

👉 TL;DR: Yakuza 0 is a masterclass in gaming that transcends the medium, offering an award-worthy blend of nostalgia, friendship, and storytelling. If you're seeking an experience that leaves an indelible mark on your heart, look no further—Yakuza 0 is a true masterpiece. 🕶️🏆

150726176.review:
[b]Standard price, AUD:[/b] $24.95

[b]Price paid, AUD:[/b] $7.86

[b]Time to finish:[/b] 113 hours. Completed the story, plus 99% of side stories but not the completionist stuff like minigames and collectibles.

[b]Difficulty setting:[/b] Normal.

[b]Graphics settings:[/b] Ultra at 3440x1440

[b][u]PC specs[/u][/b]

Motherboard: ASUS ROG STRIX Z490-E
CPU: Intel i7 10700K @ 3.8GHz
GPU: NVIDIA RTX 3080 10GB
RAM: 32GB DDR4 1600MHz
Drive: Silicone Power 500GB M.2 PCIe SSD
OS: Windows 11

[b]Performance:[/b] FPS was largely in the 60-120 FPS range with slight deviations both above and below. I never noticed any hitches or other performance related issues during gameplay.

[b]Graphics:[/b] Graphics were acceptable. Did the job, but nothing more. The only thing that was bad was some of the supporting characters’ hair that looked like glossy black play-doh.

[b]Story:[/b] Without giving anything away, there’s not actually much I can say, but I will say this. The people who came up with the story for this are some of the best. I didn’t expect to cry multiple times during the story, but that is indeed the weight and power that this story holds. Even outside of the main quests, the side stories had some great moments, too.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] I’d consider the beat ‘em up combat the main gameplay element to this game, and it does it well. Both characters have several different fighting styles. One normal, one for speed and one for power. You can also unlock a legendary fighting style through the side stories and I think there’s even another style unlocked from CP, though I didn’t grind CP enough to get it. All these styles are upgraded with money, and you gain access to locked upgrades by doing the main story and some side stories. Depending on the enemy’s fighting style, you choose your own accordingly. This requires you to think quickly when you’re surrounded by enemies of different fighting styles. All the moves feel great to use and there are plenty of flashy, cool and ridiculous moves. The heat gauge allows you to perform additional powerful moves and you can even use an array of melee and ranged weapons. All the boss fights were great. They use a combination of styles and make for a tougher battle. 

The side quests ranged from relatively normal to straight up crazy, and even ones that seemed very simple at first, quickly turned to the unexpected. I’ve heard it said that the side stories in these Yakuza games are part of what makes this game great, and I’m inclined to agree. 

The minigames were my least favourite side content in the game. I didn’t go out of my way to try these, and sometimes the game made you do them because they were tied to a quest. I had absolutely no desire to learn how to play Mahjong, for example. This stopped me from going down the completionist route. It’s not that the minigames were bad. I just didn’t enjoy it.

Each character had their own business to run, and that generated income and gave additional side stories. This was probably the most unexpectedly enjoyable part of this game for me. I sunk at least 30 hours into the business side of things alone.

The only thing I really didn’t like was the two secret boss fights that you get access to after doing all of the side stories for each character. These two fights were leagues more difficult than any other fight in the game, but most annoyingly, they were cheap, cheesy fights that were designed to infuriate. And for me, that’s exactly what they did. They can take you down from full health to 0 in a very short combo. They are relentless in their assault, they can dodge mid-attack as well as when they are getting attacked themselves, and they are incredibly hard to stagger or knock down. After dying about 30 times, I’d finally learned their unforgiving moves…and then they change fighting styles and get a power up. At this point, I went online and started looking for strategies to beat them, only to find that the way people fought these two was with very specific equipment and done in a very specific way. Without giving the method away, you can one-shot one of them after you perform a specific move. Completely cheesed. After seeing this, I decided to give up. I don’t like cheesing fights, and I don’t like bashing my head against a brick wall for 5 hours. So, I moved on.

[b]Bugs:[/b] None.

[b]Final thoughts:[/b] This game is not my usual cup of tea, but after seeing snippets of the story here and there from streamers I follow, I really wanted to experience the story. This game is filled with crazy, whacky, weird, wholesome and heartbreaking moments, tied together with an incredible story and laced with a very enjoyable combat system. I am very excited to play the rest of the games in the Yakuza series!

[b]Do I recommend this game?[/b] Yes! Even if you don’t get this on sale, it’s absolutely worth it.

150229540.review:
Yakuza 0 is a game where you can go from brutally beating up street thugs to belting out a heartfelt ballad in a karaoke bar in a matter of seconds. And that's just the tip of the iceberg!


Want to run a cabaret club? You got it! Fancy becoming a real estate tycoon? No problem! Feel like dancing your heart out in a disco club? Just head over to Maharaja! And let's not forget about the chicken... that's right, a chicken can manage your real estate. Talk about poultry in motion!


The main characters, Kiryu and Majima, are not just Yakuza. They're also part-time singers[spoiler]Baka mitai  ♡♡♡♡[/spoiler], dancers, race car drivers, baseball players, fishermen, telephone girls... you name it. They're the very definition of 'Jack of all trades'.


The storytelling hits you right in the feels one moment and then throws you into a side quest about helping a dominatrix become more confident the next. The emotional whiplash can be real, but we wouldn't have it any other way.


In essence, Yakuza 0 is a serious crime drama interspersed with the most absurd and hilarious scenarios you can imagine. It's like if The Godfather and Monty Python had a baby, and that baby was raised in Japan.


So, strap in for this rollercoaster ride of emotion and absurdity. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll wonder what the heck is going on... but most importantly, you'll have a blast. 10/10, would get punched in the face by Mr. Shakedown again

Though its a bit slow to get into at first, Yakuza 0 is one of those games you just cant put down once you get going on it. I cant stop playing it. And that's a feeling I've wanted in a game for a while. 

The main story is rich and easy to get invested in, with Iconic characters you'll be sure to obsess over. It's serious when it needs to be and funny when it wants to be. The side stories are very fun as well and you'll surely find most of them interesting, either way they are a nice distraction from the main story

 The map is lovingly crafted and beautiful to see all the neon lights at night. As somebody who's always wanted to see japan, I feel like this is the closest thing I might ever get to doing that. So many stores, shops, signs, its very detailed and pleasant look at. You can even go into some of the stores and attractions and play mini-games within them.
 
Combat is fun and fast, with different fighting styles to help with different situations.

 All of these add up to a great game that can be enjoyed throughout

This game is part of Sega's "Best of Japan" collection and I don't think there is a better way to put it.

150109082.review:
[h1]Yakuza 0 is actually a cooking simulator...because all Kiryu does is stir-fry trouble[/h1]
Yakuza 0, an open-world action-adventure game set in Japan during the 1980s. This prequel to the popular Yakuza franchise is arguably one of the best games in the series. Nearly perfect in execution, Yakuza 0 provides a richly detailed recreation of Tokyo and Osaka, Japan, with era-appropriate music and fashion. Once you start playing, you'll find yourself fully immersed in the neon-lit streets of Japan, fighting your way through the criminal underworld for hours on end. 

[h2]Gameplay [/h2]
Yakuza 0 provides an open-world action-adventure experience with role-playing elements. As players explore Tokyo and Osaka, you encounter missions and side quests at every turn. The combat is fast-paced and brutal, involving punching, kicking, throwing, and weaponry. Defeating enemies and completing missions earn money and experience to upgrade abilities.

[h3] The Combat System Is Simple Yet Deep[/h3]
The combat system in Yakuza 0 is deceptively simple yet provides depth for those who want to master it. On the surface, the controls are straightforward: light attack, heavy attack, grab, and dodge. However, there are many layers beneath this simplistic scheme.

By combining light and heavy attacks, as well as grabs and dodges, you can chain together devastating combos to take down groups of enemies. The four fighting stances—balanced, speed, power, and grab—provide different movesets for various situations. Switching between these stances opens up more possibilities in combat.

Heat actions, the brutal special moves activated when your heat gauge is full, introduce a strategic element. Do you unleash a powerful heat action to defeat one enemy instantly or save your heat to heal yourself in a pinch? The enemies you face also have different fighting styles, so you must adapt your approach to overcome their defences.

The depth in Yakuza 0's combat truly shines through in the boss battles. These lengthy, multi-stage fights against dangerous opponents feel like final exams, testing everything you've learned. Defeating a boss provides an immense sense of accomplishment due to the mental dexterity required.

[h3] Some Dated Gameplay Elements [/h3]
While Yakuza 0 excels in many areas, some of its gameplay elements feel dated. The combat system, while still fun, is basic and repetitive. Battles boil down to mashing a few buttons to throw punches and kicks at groups of enemies. There is little strategy or nuance required. The lack of variety can make long fights feel tedious.

The mission structure is similarly repetitive. Most missions involve little more than going to a location, watching a cutscene, and then brawling with a group of thugs. Rinse and repeat. There are a few standout missions that break from the formula, but the majority follow a predictable pattern. Adding more puzzle-solving, stealth, investigative work, or other types of objectives would help mix up the mission types and pacing.

That said, the story, characters, world-building, and humour are so superb that the repetitive gameplay is easy to overlook. 

[h3] Difficulty Spikes Can Be Frustrating [/h3]
When you first start playing, the basic combat mechanics seem simple enough to grasp. You have a light attack, heavy attack, grab, and dodge at your disposal. However, as you progress through the game, increasingly more complex enemy types are introduced that require intricate strategies and combination attacks to defeat. Some boss fights ramp up the difficulty so sharply that you may find yourself stuck, unable to progress further, no matter how many attempts you make.

Rather than gradually increasing the difficulty through the natural progression of the game, Yakuza 0 throws players into the deep end at times. To advance past these roadblocks, you have no choice but to spend time grinding - repeating easier missions to gain experience points, money, and resources to upgrade your character. The grinding required can feel tedious and dull in comparison to the otherwise fast-paced action of the game.

While a challenging experience is appreciated, the difficulty spikes in Yakuza 0 are severe enough that they cross the line from engaging to annoying. The steep learning curve for mastering combat and overcoming certain bosses means that less skilled or patient players may become frustrated and give up on the game altogether. Smoothing out the difficulty progression and providing more guidance for developing combat skills would make the gameplay in Yakuza 0 nearly flawless.

[h2] The Story and Characters Are Engaging [/h2]
The story of Yakuza 0 is set in 1988 Japan, during an economic boom. You play as Kazuma Kiryu and Goro Majima, two yakuza members who find themselves in the middle of a conspiracy within the criminal underworld.

The narrative is split between Kiryu in Tokyo and Majima in Osaka, creating two engaging tales that eventually intertwine. Kiryu is a level-headed enforcer trying to clear his name after being framed for murder, while Majima is an eccentric club owner aiming to rejoin the yakuza. Both protagonists are likable and complex, with interesting backstories and motivations.

Supporting characters are similarly multifaceted. The villains have understandable reasons behind their actions instead of being generically evil. Allies become friends that you form genuine connections with over the course of the story. Memorable subplots and side quests also help to flesh out minor characters and build investment in the world.

With its blend of humour, drama and hard-boiled crime fiction, Yakuza 0's story is a thrill ride from start to finish. The game does an excellent job of pulling you in with its charismatic characters and high-stakes narrative. Whether you're a long-time fan of the series or completely new, this prequel entry is not to be missed.

[h2]Vibrant Neon-Lit Cities [/h2]
The game is set in Kamurocho, Tokyo and Sotenbori, Osaka, both of which are modelled after the Kabukicho and Dotombori entertainment districts. These areas come to life with crowded streets, neon signs, pachinko parlours, and nightclubs - all hallmarks of 1980s Japan. Exploring these dense urban environments transports the player back in time and provides context for the underlying themes of economic prosperity and indulgence in the era.

Walking down the cluttered alleyways and streets, you encounter many distractions, from ramen carts to disco clubs to pay phones ringing. The lively city hubs are filled with details that make the world feel lived-in and bustling. All of these elements combine to deliver an authentic depiction of the exuberant economic boom in 1980s Japan.

The game's soundtrack also deserves mention, with catchy synth-pop and electronic beats that were popular during this time period, adding another layer of '80s ambience. The music creates a sense of cultural nostalgia for those who grew up or lived in Japan during this era.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
Overall, Yakuza 0 richly deserves the critical acclaim and fan devotion it has garnered. For those seeking a memorable story and virtual tourism in 1980s Japan, Yakuza 0 is a must-play game that hits nearly all the right notes. While a few minor missteps keep it from absolute perfection, Yakuza 0 is a title that will stick with players long after the credits roll. It is a game that succeeds in tugging at heartstrings while still making you laugh and in crafting a world so lush you can nearly smell the ramen and cigarettes. Yakuza 0 is an experience not soon forgotten.

149183966.review:
I've just finished the game on hard and even though I overall enjoyed the game mostly because of its style, story and characters, I have to give it a bad review, mostly to warn people like me who might get swayed by the sea of positive reviews into thinking that this game got everything right. It didn't, and here are my reasons:

-Combat system:
The game has 3 combat styles for each character, with plenty of over the top moves to unlock that make the fights very satisfying. When you're fighting multiple weaker opponents there's some strategy and a lot of button mashing but overall the fights are fun and let you be creative.
It's when you're fighting high level enemies that things go terribly wrong and the combat system becomes boring, random and very frustrating. Strong enemies will of course counterattack much more than regular enemies, but there seems to be no logic or rule on this. Sometimes you can get long combos on them and sometimes they will dodge and counterattack after 2 punches. This becomes a problem especially when they powerup at the second stage of the fight. When you dodge a powerful attack and end up behind them you expect to have some sort of reward right? They should be open to at least a short combo, right? But no, even if you go for a simple light>light>heavy (or even just light>heavy) they sometimes do a 180 and hit you in the face with a move too fast to react. If you manage to hit them with strong attacks sometimes you get punished because they'll recover before you do. Grabs also stop working after a few succesful throws, and that's fine, except sometimes they still do but I found no logic behind that, just another thing that seems completely based on rng.
What happens is that the best strategy for fighting these bosses is running around like a chicken without locking, waiting for an opening to land like 2 hits and then keep running. For me it was mostly a problem with Majima, because Kiryu has a fast style that lets you dodge mid-combo, so I did a lot of his hard fights by spamming attacks and dodging randomly and it worked pretty well.
I thought I didn't understand the fightsystem, but when I looked up youtube videos, everyone was playing exactly like me.
You can stock up on healing items that you can use from the pause menu and brute force through every tough encounter in the game, but that's pretty lame.

-Minigames:
The game is known for being filled with content, sidequests, minigames and collectibles to an insane level. Personally I find it a bit too much, the game just wants to tickle that part of your brain that wants to 100% a game even if it's not fun anymore, so you'll go around and try to eat every food, collect every card, and complete every minigame.
But back to the minigames: there's so many of them and some have some sort of complexity and even come with side-stories that require a lot of time and effort to be completed...I personally wouldn't play most of them even if they paied me, but since they're optional that's no problem. My problem was mainly with business activities: to level up your characters you need money and at some point the money you make from missions is not enough anymore, so the best way to make money is through business activities, which are yet another minigame.
Business activities are just time-wasting, dopamine-releasing minigames. You just have to play a lot, see numbers grow up, click things to spend money to make more money, watch money go up and feel like a drug addict, you're no better than you grandmother playing facebook games when playing these. I have to say that al least the cabaret club has some gameplay and strategy to it, but it requires soo much time of repetitive gameplay to complete a working day, upgrading your hostesses and running around town to find business partners.
The real estate business is even worse. It just requires you to go around town, buy some property, go back to the office to start money collection, wait around, go back to the office to get the money, invest in every property and start collection again, then go around town again to buy new properties with exponentially increasing prices, rinse and repeat.
Unfortunately you have to spend some time "playing" these minigames to unlock your abilites and to beat the final mission without filling your inventory with healing items.

TL;DR: Combat system is random and tedious when facing strong opponents. Minigames will fuck your dopamine reward system up

So that's all, as I said I overall enjoyed the game but I don't think I'll play any more yakuza games unless there are some big changes in the combat system

149015869.review:
The Yakuza series is a gargantuan undertaking full of lengthy, complex games and SEGA has done little to ease this barrier of entry until Yakuza 0. This title is the definitive gateway for those of you hopped on Baka Mitai memes and constantly distracted by intrusive thoughts of Goro Majima. At times you may find yourself itching to buy a plane ticket to Japan, or questioning why Kiryu Kazama isn’t in Tekken yet (he doesn’t hit women), but for those who want instant gratification and would like to avoid spending thousands of dollars travelling, this is your answer. 

What might surprise you is Yakuza 0 is even funnier than its memes. The game’s humor and writing shines through its side-quests, which showcases outlandish scenarios and memorable goofball characters. To balance this, the main story features a deep criminal conspiracy involving two differing points-of-view. While the pacing is glacial at times and requires a lot of patience, the payoff is exhilarating. Accompanying this is action gameplay that is easy to learn and has surprising depth. 

Unfortunately, Yakuza 0 sets the bar on storytelling and gameplay so high that some of the later titles pale in comparison. Combat can be sometimes frustrating due to an uncooperative camera, and certain heat attack timings are unnecessarily strict. Zero also struggles from a rare case of having too much content, and it’s clear that the quality of its minigames is imbalanced. While the main game has a slew of tedious but helpful tutorials, games such as Shogi and Mahjong are infamous for doing very little to teach players how to play with any form of competence. The result is a few addictive minigames and a handful that players will avoid like the plague. 

Completionists beware, 100%ing this game is very frustrating. For everyone else just wanting to get into the series, this is the place.

148998792.review:
[i]Kiryu-chann![/i]

[i]Yakuza 0[/i] is quintessential Yakuza. It is what introduced so many people to the franchise. It is where a large portion of the memes came from. Many consider it to be the best in the franchise - and perhaps for well deserved reasons.

[h1]Shortly[/h1]
Yakuza 0 is a dark game set in the bubble of 1980's Japan, where a small bit of land from the Imperial Palace was worth more than the entirety of the US region of California. Money is a central concept in the game, gained from beating up mobs from generic thugs to properly fleshed out story bosses, often coming out hundreds of thousands of yen richer from each battle. The bubble shows and rears its head often. Upgrades hit the tens of millions and hundreds of millions-zone early on, and you become even more of a money machine than before.

In the midst of this neon paradise however, you will come closer acquainted to the criminal underworld of Tokyo's very own Kamurocho, and perhaps even the concrete - all the while wrapped up in a murder mystery that's clearly bigger and more intricate than it would have you believe, which will take Kiryu through highs and lows that test his personality and mold him into his own person.

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
-Neon streets.
-Kamurocho.
-Absolutely well made world that [i]feels[/i] like a bustling city in the 80s, where people no longer know how to spend their cash.
-A significantly more noir-like story compared to the other games that came before, in stark contrast to what comes after Y0.
-Variety in heat actions.
-Satisfying combat.
-Cool characters.
-A story you don't want to miss.
-Side content abundance.
-There are so. Many. Different. Heat Actions.
-The game is very humorous.
-Character development.
-Two playable characters.


-The music.
The damn music.
-Dynamic intros - the painting-like way characters pose before a battle, are so unadulteratedly good, and cool.
-Kiryu. Is. So. Damn. Cool.

[b]Cons[/b]
-For someone whose first introduction to Yakuza is this game, the console-only nature of the franchise will be jarring at first. Keyboard may not be as optimal as controller, but it is still effective and not hard once you get a grasp for the game and it's mechanics.
-For anyone in the West, it will also undoubtedly be very strange witnessing Japanese game design and writing in action.
>The game, like other games in the series, suffers from tropes and clichés that you will absolutely be able to see coming for yourself, reducing the impact of the gameplay and story.
-Strange game design decisions every now and then. You will also know who is an NPC and who is a main/side character based off on looks alone. It gets old rather fast, and the characters sometimes look strange or similar with little variety - of which most is reserved primarily for the main cast.
-Without cheesing, it becomes a bit of a chore acquiring more money to level yourself up with.
-Some side content (which is also shoehorned in the main story missions) is... NSFW, to say the least - such as betting on women wearing almost nothing wrestling with eachother.
-The game's 2 playable characters *may* make it a bit disjointed following the main story, and it inevitably results in less content for each character. However, it's rather well done in Yakuza 0, especially compared to further entries, so it is far less noticeable.
-It's subtitled in English, but everything else is in Japanese. Voice acting can be dealt with, but sometimes it gets tiring only seeing Japanese letters that you can't get a read on.
-The game's hardest difficulty - Legend - makes the game's design flaws and combat flaws become all the more apparent. Not being able to save whereever you want, having NO checkpoints, being forced to restart from the last save if you die, (or don't even die - but just simply fail a substory..) it's ridiculous. I believe not many have qualms about using cheats to finish the job when the game also actively works against you while you can also not counter that.
Who. Asked. For. Escort. Missions.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game begins with exposition revealing who you are and general details of the main character and his story, while introducing you to the mechanics of the game. Eventually, you get to grips with the combat system - heat actions, grabs, throws, combos, and fighting styles. 
You, quite literally, canonically eat money to become stronger. The world is full of random encounters, and each hit gives you more money.

As there is little to no multiplayer, being a mainly singleplayer game, there are no updates.

[h1]Community[/h1]
Yakuza 0's - Yakuza's community may have a reputation for being [i]everywhere[/i] much like you could say JoJo fans are everywhere. The same JoJo logic also applies to Yakuza fans, spamming out memeable clips and basing personalities, names and entire online presences around Yakuza characters while constantly spitting out Yakuza references.
It is merely a vocal minority, but it is an imprint people will still have, regardless.

But for a franchise with someone in it who is so cool that he has a tattoo of a fucking [b]dragon[/b] on his back, is called the Dragon [DoD] much like Katana Zero (sooo coool!!) and is incredibly strong in combat and is also a tough bad boy [i]with[/i] emotions, I cannot blame them for it.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics are very good. Naturally, cutscenes are 2 times more fleshed out than anything in gameplay would be, but normal gameplay looks very good even if it screams "this is a console game" - worldbuilding is awesome, but what's disappointing is the normal dialogue you have with NPCs. Character models are an upgrade over Sims 3's pudding-faces, but they aren't exactly what you'd expect from a 2018 PC game.

Cutscenes, though? Pleasing to look at. Well made. So good. 
And some of them even have potential as desktop wallpapers - at times, even profile pictures.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
Yakuza 0's soundtrack is certainly an experience. At first, it won't seem too notable. Singing forced karaoke and finding out this is where the funny meme song came from, you likely won't think much of it still.
As the fights go on and you progress in the story, you start realizing that the soundtrack isn't generic or mediocre. It's damn well above it.
Your archrival will have a very aggressive rock-like, guitar-heavy track that you will be very familiar with by the end of the game. But by the end of the game, you notice something. It's no longer aggressive. It's not antagonistic anymore. It's even hopeful, in a sense.
Songs are aptly named and fit their characters. Your buddy has a well-fitting 1980s-like upbeat, energetic, hopeful power beat. A foreign assassin has a menacing, hostile theme. Some bosses have a more generic boss track, but even it works for them as a strange, electronic guitar beat.
And the final boss's track... is better experienced by playing the game through till its' end.

To go on about listing the minute differences that make each song great would be a feat to make even Sisyphus happy, though. It's best to simply play the game and listen to the OSTs by oneself.

[h1]Conclusion, Final Words[/h1]
Yakuza 0 is a banger of a game in more than one way. Not much of it leaves the player unsatisfied or frustrated.
It is an experience through and through, best enjoyed without spoilers, listening to the music anywhere else other than ingame, or even checking out Yakuza-related media beforehand.
Yakuza 0's poses, fighting moves, and characters are cool, all in a primal way. They just [i]are[/i] even if tattooed shirtless men fighting other tattooed shirtless men doesn't sound as cool on paper.

Not being able to understand a word of Japanese is no barrier to playing this game. Even without further intention of buying more Yakuza games or the collection, it's good to play through Y0 at least once. At 20€, it's not even a big hit on your wallet buying it. Or 5€, for who waits for a sale.

[b]9/10[/b]

Title: A Riveting Dive into the Yakuza Underworld

Review:

Yakuza 0 is an enthralling journey into the heart of Japan's criminal underworld, brought to life with a level of detail and depth that is nothing short of remarkable. Developed by Ruy Ga Gotoku Studio and published by SEGA, this game stands as a testament to the heights that the open-world action-adventure genre can achieve.

Set against the neon-lit backdrop of 1980s Tokyo and Osaka, Yakuza 0 offers an immersive experience that seamlessly combines a gripping narrative with a myriad of activities. The game's compelling storyline follows the lives of Kazuma Kiryu and Goro Majima, delving deep into their backgrounds and motivations. The character development is nothing short of exceptional; you'll find yourself emotionally invested in their struggles, triumphs, and growth.

One of the standout features of Yakuza 0 is its vibrant and meticulously recreated open world. The bustling streets, filled with NPCs going about their lives, create a living, breathing environment that truly immerses you in the game. The attention to detail is astounding, from the authenticity of the locations to the diverse range of side activities. Whether you're managing a cabaret club, playing classic Sega games, or engaging in intense street fights, there's always something engaging to do.

Combat in Yakuza 0 is dynamic and satisfying. The game strikes a perfect balance between brawling and strategic elements, allowing for a variety of fighting styles that cater to different playstyles. Each encounter feels intense and impactful, making you feel like a true martial arts master.

Moreover, the game's narrative is complemented by exceptional voice acting, capturing the nuances of the characters' emotions effectively. The soundtrack deserves special mention, as it skillfully enhances the atmosphere, ranging from intense battle themes to soulful melodies that resonate long after you've put down the controller.

In addition to its main story, Yakuza 0 offers a plethora of side quests and mini-games, adding layers of depth to an already rich experience. Whether you're solving the problems of the locals, participating in karaoke sessions, or engaging in high-stakes card games, these diversions never feel like filler and contribute significantly to the game's overall charm.

Yakuza 0 on Steam shines not only for its captivating storytelling and gameplay but also for its technical excellence. The PC version boasts smooth performance, allowing players to enjoy the game at its best, even on a wide range of hardware configurations.

In summary, Yakuza 0 stands as a crowning achievement in gaming. Its blend of an immersive open world, compelling characters, diverse gameplay, and technical polish make it an absolute must-play title for fans of the genre. Whether you're a newcomer to the series or a longtime fan, this game is an unforgettable experience that sets a new standard for what an open-world game can achieve.

Score: 10/10 - A Masterpiece

148346437.review: Yeah this game is pretty great. I beat this game already on PS4 when i had one a while back along with Kiwami, Kiwami 2, (skipped 3 but watched every cutscene to keep up with the story cuz i didn't enjoy the gameplay) beat 4, and I'm working on 5 and moving on to 6 afterwards. But 0 is an fun begging story to those both Familiar and Unfamiliar with the story of Yakuza. If you haven't played any of these games and do not know the story and are looking to get into it from beginning to end, Start with this one, it is worth the play. First off, learning the backstory of two of the most loved characters in Yakuza, Kiryu, and Majima, Each having unique styles of fighting, and two separate places to explore, Kiryu mainly taking place in Kamurocho, and Majima taking place in Sotenbori. And not to mention two huge minigames/side stories for both characters (which i am guilty of spending far to long on) however if you can get yourself through them both, you unlock their secret styles which they will be seen using in future games. There are a lot of cutscenes, and usually that takes me away from most games, but considering Yakuza is know for it's more serious story, and it's absolute bonkers side quest, i cannot help but be interested and have my eyes glued to the screen to keep my eyes on whats happening next. The gameplay and using these styles to fight enemies is pretty damn fun, the Heat Moves are extremely brutal, and it's fun finding out more you can do and what you can learn in the future. If Resident Evil didn't exist and make my childhood for gaming amazing, then this game series would be my favorite series out there today. It is so fun and actually a great time, 100% better than Grand Theft Auto ever could hope to be in my opinion. If you haven't played any Yakuza game in the series, or you have played almost all or all of them except this one, you owe it to yourself to play this one.

148291302.review:
"Yo... Kiryu-chan!"

- Goro Majima

===================================================================

My first ever Yakuza game. First things first, for everyone who's going to try to 100% this game like me, I'd like to tell you that you have to prepare yourself for hours of frustration. But, it is still possible to do with patience and resilience, of course. The Game Mechanic is really good and the Graphic also looks awesome. The battle is okay but it's getting kinda annoying near the end of the game. What I really love from this game is that it feels like it's never running out of content to give. I never got bored getting from 1 place to another because you'll be faced with either enemies or Side Quests. There are many things to explore from Restaurants, Equipment, and even Mini Games.

Now, talking about Mini Games, these are the things that will make you frustrated for getting 100% Achievements. The mechanics of the Mini Games are different from each other and kinda hard to master. Like there are billiard, roulette, batting center, even Arcade Games that each contain their own mechanics. Some of them are quite RnG heavy, so even if you already understand the rules or how to beat the Mini Game, chance is you probably still need to retry many more times before getting the Achievement. But, other than those things related to Achievement, and especially if you want to play just to enjoy, then this Game is so rich in Narrative and Battle. You can explore many Fighting Styles and combine them with various weapons. The Plot is intriguing to the point that I can't wait to see/learn more of it as the Chapters go. The Main Story itself can tear your heart apart, but the Side Stories are also really good.

===================================================================

I'm gonna give this game a "Baka Mitai" out of "24-hour Cinderella"

148129949.review:
I reached the final chapter of the game and instead of finishing it up, I decided to get on with the sidestories and write this review. This one is personal because 1) it's my first time writing an actual review, 2) it's the first game I actually complete totally by myself. I'm not what you'd call a "gamer" and I usually enjoy inviting friends over to play together or ask 'em for hints, tips etc. But this one is mine alone. I will divide the review into sections:

- Story - 
The story is literally like a really well-made crime thriller, set in old Japan, during the days of Yakuza. Great character archetypes, action, drama, emotion, exceptionally interesting plot with well-written plot twists and amazing atmosphere (more details on that below)

- Gameplay -
Some might not find the combat system interesting, it revolves around stances that your 2 playable characters use, each with a unique set of moves/special actions. Basically what happens pre battle is that you stumble upon some hostile fellas and the fight begins, once you wipe 'em all out, the fight scene ends and you're back from where you left. Boss fights or special fights are the same, there's a scene being displayed, combat starts, finishes and scene goes on. The game is focused on martial arts and pure brawling so don't expect anything Mortal Kombat-like. The "Abilities" section in the menu allows you to spend money you collect on upgrading your battle stances. NOTE: You DON'T need to upgrade all the stances or all the skills of one stance to the maximum, you can finish the game by having incomplete stance skill trees but unlocking the 100% of a stance is legit broken but requires an amount of grind. Smooth movement across a Japanese background, historically accurate, well-depicted scenery and random spots around town that serve as restaurants, shops or places of interest in general. You're free to enter any shop, eat and restore HP, train into your battle stances, play old Sega arcade games and other minigames (e.g. bowling, darts and more) or buy items you can carry around in your inventory. Also includes an Item Box as an option.

- Main story & substories - 
I'll start off by saying that Yakuza 0 is basically 40% gameplay and 60% watching. For some, this isn't a good thing, while others find the story captivating and don't mind at all (like me). Substories are of course an optional part, however there are so many funny, witty, well-written substories, that I'd encourage any player to complete as many as they can. By completing substories, you gain some sort of points that you can exchange at certain places in the city called "shrines" for buffs or perks. The best thing about the main story and the sidestories is that the game overall serves as a small history lesson. You get a peak of '80s Japan, when technology started thriving, the economy started booming and the transition between old and new took place. The way people speak, eat, respect, show honor, betray, party, it's all as realistic as it gets. There are references to history, economic subjects, pop culture, innovations of that period, Japanese pornstars (I'm not joking), the yakuza code and so much more. There's one type of collectible items, which is old telephone cards you can find at random places on the street. On these cards, there are pictures of Japanese women and their real names. With a quick Google search, you see that these women are indeed Japanese real-life actresses in adult films. 

- Minigames -
Haven't tried them all myself but most of them are fun, especially the karaoke. Different gameplay for each one with secret achievements or substories following their successful completion. The main "big" minigames are that of Kamurocho Real Estate (1st protagonist) and the Cabaret Club (2nd protagonist). Completion for these requires too many hours (this is where I am currently), but it's optional of course. The more you play 'em though, gives you access to even more content, part of which is so witty and funny

- Cons -
Some might find it slow-burn. If the story doesn't attract you, you'll probably wanna just get done with it. The real estate and cabaret minigames might feel like a drag and combat might be considered flat since you don't have a huge variety of moves. Friends of mine have called it boring from time to time; it's not a game you can launch and hope to complete part of the story in 20 minutes time for example. Cutscenes might take enough of your time so you end up playing for 1.5 hours cause in between the cinematics you didn't have a phone booth to save your progress (yeah, your save points are phone booths scattered around the city). Thank god I don't go with none of them possible cons.

An amazing experience that will soon end. If you read the whole thing, thank you so much for reading my feelings about it. Onwards to Yakuza Kiwami 1

147970570.review:
🎶👊 Brawling, Business, and... Karaoke? - A Stroll through Yakuza 0’s Diverse Streets 👊🎶

Hey, fellow gamers,

🌟Rating: 9.5/10🌟

High Notes & Heavy Hits:

Karaoke Extravaganza: The karaoke mini-game isn’t just a side activity; it’s AAA+ excellence and a delightful pause from the main narrative, offering joy in each note.

Soundtrack Magic: An exceptional soundtrack flawlessly envelopes each moment, scene, and action, becoming a character in its own right within the world of Yakuza.

Multifaceted Storytelling: Offering not one but multiple perspectives, the game enthralls with its layered narratives, where friendships are tested and alliances are never quite what they seem.

Strategic Brawling: Combat is a calculated dance of various fighting styles, providing both a strategic and visceral joy in every encounter.

The Charming Details:

80s Vibrance: The spirit of the 80s is ever-present, with every neon light and pop-culture nod (cheers, MJ!) immersing you deeper into its lively world.

Edgy Collectibles: Those risqué VHS card collections offer an eyebrow-raising but cheeky distraction, adding a dash of edgy humor without crossing the line.

Side Business Excellence: The business management mini-game is a rich and rewarding escapade, providing a substantial and intriguing diversion from the main plot.

Varied Side Stories: Each side quest stands as its own mini-narrative, blending heart, humor, and the right dash of Yakuza’s signature absurdity.

Imperfections:

While there are few to mention, some may find a couple of the side activities (like the cheeky VHS collections) a bit much, but they’re tucked into a vast array of other endeavors and easily skipped if not your cup of tea.

Parting Words:

Yakuza 0 manages to weave a tale that’s as deeply moving as it is wildly entertaining, crafting a universe that’s both brutally intense and inexplicably whimsical. Whether it's the emotional depths, thrilling brawls, or simply a desire to hit those karaoke high notes - there’s something here for everyone.

And so, from one guy just enjoying his everyday life in the vibrant, bustling streets of Kamurocho to another: welcome, and may your journey through these neon-lit nights be as thrilling as the tales that have unfolded in my playthrough.

Tip of the hat to you, fellow adventurer. 🎩🌃

Happy gaming

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

I picked up a few games from this franchise, this game included, because several people were talking highly of the series. My expectations were not inflated by this, I tried it out with an open mind. After experiencing several aspects of this game, I have started regretting bying multiple Yakuza games.

There's a stark contrast between what this game could have been and what it is; Some story quests feature full voice acting and fitting sound and visual effects, while the majority of the missions and street encounters are heavily text-reliant and feature stiff characters who only grunt or utter the occasional "Nani?!?". The semi-open world is very limited, and often features only a few linear paths with little room for exploration. This world includes many components which attempt to bring the world to life, but it still suffers from limitations, repeated events such as street thugs on every other corner which gets old fast, and a confusing map system. My biggest gripe with the gameplay is that the game does not tell you what to do or where to go half of the time, which leads to confusion and the need to consult guides and walkthroughs online. Many aspects of the game feel like they were limited or cut due to budget reasons, and the player experience suffers as a result. The only highlights from my 10 hours of playing were the dance mini games and the combat which was somewhat decent and varied.

I would recommend making your own critical assessment of this game before trying it out - It's very highly spoken of by some, but may not be for everyone. The disappointment of this first Yakuza game and the tedious gameplay has not left me wanting more of the series.

147545844.review:
This is a very nice game that presents to the player the country of Japan, its traditions, its culture and the way the mafia live their life. It has heart warming, incredible stories. It has some of the most entertaining music and funny events I have ever seen, and the Disco, is just great!

Then why am I not recommending it? Well, although the music, the story and some mini-games are fun to play, there is a huge annoyance that remains constant throughout the game, and that is: The Combat

Walking peacefully down the streets? Combat. Something happened in the story? Combat. Something happened in the sub story? Combat....  Combat, Combat, Combat and more Combat.

But normally combat is the fun part right?
Yes, it is supposed to be fun. Unfortunately, for me, it is not.

Let me explain:
All abilities and combat skills are locked away from you in the beginning, but its not like its the extra stuff, its actually the basic stuff that is locked away.
Normal Dodge? Locked. Normal Block? Locked. Make more than 2 attack combos? Locked. 
Then after unlocking the basic stuff you want to AIM to the enemies, well good luck with that!
Enemies can rotate around you and make a very annoying combo then drop you to the ground, once you are hit, you cannot escape, you are stun locked and will receive the full combo, you will stand there like a sandbag and receive it all against your will. Once the enemy has finished the combo, your protagonist slowly falls to the ground and stays there until you mash a button for what seems like an eternity, after that, it will stand up only to repeat everything all over again if you don't dodge as the first action you take. And believe me, it is a pain in the royal ass to feel useless and smash a button that almost doesn't seem to do anything just so the character you are controlling finally stands up from its eternal slumber.

Then the developers knew that there was a problem. Fighting 1v1 works. But add 1 more opponent to the formula and its a train wreck...for the player.
So what did they do? They used something called "Heat Actions" which automatically makes a combo for you? Why? because they noticed that their combat was very frustrating and having mini cut scenes of combat was going to fix everything, but guess what? Heat Actions are also Locked from you until you get enough in-game money to unlock them, so the solution has to be reached by the player. But to unlock them you either have more and more Combat, or do side mission with guess what, more Combat.

The ending of the game is also not satisfactory, plot armor is visible throughout the last chapters and the hand of the game designers can be seen conveniently making events happen out of the blue and trying to convince the audience that characters can behave not like themselves just to alter the outcome of an obvious event.

I am new to the Yakuza franchise and can say that this is a great Japan simulator, i have traveled to Tokyo and Osaka and man this game shows the cities very nicely, I can feel I am there just by remembrance.

But if you don't care about gimmicky combat, hours and hours of grind, but absolutely love anything Japan related and can swallow the pain pill it causes, then this game may be for you.

Tl:dr
I hate the Combat in this game. Check other websites and videos to know more about it.
Story ending: Unsatisfactory

147531239.review:
8/10

Pros:
- Combat is surprisingly fun. Variety like different styles and different Heat Bursts (short cut scene special moves) helps
- Wide variety of mini-games. Can't really name a "bad" mini-game and a few really stand out as quite good like Cabaret and Real Estate.
- Side stories are varied and (in my opinion) hilarious, even if they're not PC!

Neither here nor there:
- For the age of the game, the graphics are decent enough though it does suffer a little here and there as a PC port.
- Main story is fine and functional but is rather safe. So I guess it does it's job but not much more.
- The music is actually quite good with some excellent hooks and a few stand-outs, but it often lacks variety and personality. 

Cons:
- Missed opportunities with 2 protagonists - too many shared qualities
- In the main story, there's quite a few forgettable 2D people who are just archetypes really
- Not a fan of the unvoiced sections. Even a handful of side character voices would go a long way rather than just hearing "hai!" or "um!" every now and then.

Overall:

A solid, safe game with a great premise (basically anime meets a mafia movie). However, I don't feel like it pushes enough new ground despite some interesting ideas like 2 protagonists. Everything from the story to the music reflects this. Still, can't argue too much with a fun game.

147487840.review:
Chronologically, Yakuza 0 is the first game in the series. However, it was developed after Yakuza 5, which means it is one of the later Yakuza games in the franchise. Being a prequel, it rewards players who already have established knowledge of the plot lines in later games 'cause it gives a lot of new perspective on some key characters (Nishikiyama and Majima in particular), while also giving fresh newcomers a wonderful starting point in the series. And in this way Yakuza 0 is pretty clever, because veterans will want to replay the 1 and 2 remakes (Kiwami games) after finishing this story, and newcomers will most likely want to see how the story continues in the Yakuza saga.

The story is as ever the strongest point, with some flaws that have always been with Yakuza. That being the jarring dissonance between what occurs in the gameplay and what actually happens in the story. So much so that you might as well consider the gameplay non-canon, as watching Kiryu literally shank yakuza with a knife to their innards or shoot down guys in helicopters are some few examples of the narrative contradicting what it preaches later on. If you can suspend your disbelief for these moments, then the plot won't be ruined for you as the drama, characters, and suspense will all keep you going.

The gameplay is alright. I love my action games, and Yakuza 0 does enough to hold interest with its brutal, brawling gameplay. Though it is a little jank as well as bosses often have lots of superarmour, and won't really let you use HEAT actions (which are the most gratifying part of the combat). There's no shame in picking the Easy difficulty for this reason for the story is far more enticing than the combat. There are tons of mini-games and hilarious sidequests too that are a good distraction from the heavy plot if you just need a break from all the drama.

Overall, Yakuza 0 is a fun ride. The story can get a little dumb at times, but it also delivers one of the best plot threads the series has to offer. If you can just revel in the fun, then honestly that's all you need. Just enjoy the craziness, the over-the-top nonsense, and the genuine moments when the story delivers on its plot points and excellent characters.

I'm booting up Kiwami right as I finish typing this review. Majima is the best.

147214529.review:
Yakuza 0 hits, pun intended. This was my first Yakuza game and I was seriously impressed with its writing, voice acting, streamlined beat em up gameplay, sheer amount of content, musical score, and animations.  Pretty much everything about this game delivered. I would absolutely recommend it for fans of fighting games and narrative RPGs, even for newcomers to the series like me. 

Maybe 1/3 of my gameplay time is spent watching cutscenes. Strictly speaking about the main story, you are basically watching a movie in which you play the fight scenes and the parts where you walk around town. But that was fine by me, I thought the story was excellent, weaving a complex and interesting mafia story with twists and turns that kept you on your toes. There is a lot to unpack here, but suffice to say, I really enjoyed it, not being a typical fan of these types of things. 

The game offers a massive amount of content. My 27 hour playthrough was mostly focused on the main story, with a few hours dipping into the extras and side quests. I felt like a barely scratched the surface of the game. Both two main characters have about 100 side quests between them and both of them have a fully fleshed out business side storyline that I barely made any progress on. I could see this game offering an interested player 70-100 hours of gameplay easy. 

The sounds design was excellent. SFX was great, the soundtrack hit just right during the action sequences but also during the more tonally serious bits. The game is subtitled, and the voice acting is in Japanese, but none the less I could tell it was delivered with passion and quality from the voice actors. 

The game doesn’t offer a particularly big open world, but the two main explorable areas are jam packed with content. 

My only gripe is a relatively minor one, the writing includes many interesting characters but absolutely  no well written female characters. There is only three and they are all poorly written in my opinion. I get that the yakuza is a male institution, but the game had so may throw away civilian characters maybe one of them could have been a cool fem.

All in all I really appreciated my time with this game. Its narrative was excellent, its beat em up gameplay with just complex enough to keep my interest. I would recommend this game for sure.

147103011.review:
I'm going to preface this review with the fact that I'm an aspiring writer. And that is all it really is, is a preface. It has less to do with this review itself than you'd think.

I have been writing since I was sixteen years old. And every time I wrote, I wrote to bring myself wealth. 'This is going to be the one, I just know it'.

Blatant lies of a fool with hopes stronger than the legs he stood on. I've never gotten past page 50, let alone page 100. I always redesign my work, 'this should go here' or 'I don't think that'll sell like that there'. It was all in the name of securing what I wanted with monetary gain.


Then, one day I stopped writing.

Too many mess ups, too many times I had thought of the 'thousand dollar winner that'd put me ahead in life'. And too many times I had lost hope. If I couldn't sell my book, what was the reason to do it?

And then I played Yakuza 0. 

As my first Yakuza game, I had already heard the praise long ahead of actually enjoying it. Kiwami's Majima Everywhere system had become a meme in my recommendations, and I had previously listened to the music on my own. So I knew I was getting into something good.

As characters came and went, they were interesting—some downright amazing—but nothing exactly life changing. Kiryu was a bad ass and righteous, Nishkiyama was trustworthy and loyal,  Kuze was conniving and brutish, and Majima was just generally depressing at times. But there were two characters that changed how I view my life.

Major spoilers for Chapter 8 onwards ahead.

The first actually appeared in Chapter 8, a man by the name Nishitani. He starts off as your enemy, making you go the extra mile to get a kick out of fighting you. However in the very end, Nishitani gives his life avenging his Uncle B, and makes a request of Majima; to blaze his own path, and live life how he sees fit.

Then, at a later moment, there's an after-scene of the fight with Awano. Awano spent his life on dazzling lights and accelerated highs. While he was basking in the limelight, he never took a chance to really enjoy it. And in the very end, he also died, a life of wasted potential thrown away.

And these men got me thinking; what have I been writing for? Who have I been writing for, if not for me? And I made a decision, then and there.

I'm not going to write to sell my book any more. If it comes to that, then fine, my dreams can be reawakened. But until that becomes a reality, which could very well never be, I'm going to write to make a story I want to live by. A dream I want to fashion myself rather than the clouds that hang above my head. Could I never even get close? It's a well possibility. But I'm going to take that chance as long as it brings me joy; I'm going to live my way, for myself, and I won't dare squander an opportunity to prove my skill to myself.

In the end, I'm no longer trying to win the world over—I'm the one I'm trying to impress.

146985095.review:
This is some of the most fun I've had with a video game in many years.

The first few chapters are a steady drip of story, side quests and activities around town (karaoke, disco, bowling, etc). After that, the Real Estate and Cabaret Club activities open up and the game gets really addicting. The game actively encourages you to engage with all of the side content as it improves your overall standing in the world, on top of giving you more abilities for your various fighting styles. 

You unlock various moves with cash money and the combat actively rewards you for varying your moves by providing more cash in each random (or linear) encounter. I am constantly engaged with everything in the world and it's so refreshing to play an open world game that rewards you for spending as much time in it as possible. For such a small map, there is so much to do and you can spend hours upon hours and still miss things. I've clocked 40 hours and I'm only about 2/3 of the way through the story, because I've been having so much fun with Cabaret Club and pursuing all the side content. 

If you're a fan of beat-em-up style games, open world RPG's, engaging and creative NPC side quests, memorable characters (in the side stories as well) then this game is for you. The creativity on display here is like nothing I've ever seen.

146167053.review:
Such Fun with much gameplay Elements. One thing you will find hard to do is get bored.......unless you are watching one of the 10 million year long cutscenes with so much exposition dump that made me think that Quantum Physics would be easier to summarise AND UNDERSTAND in the same time. It is quirky and FUN game nonetheless with a lot of character. Comments can be made about that "character" but overlooking that, worth the 100+ hours i have put into it, mostly spent watching said cutscenes.

The gameplay can be accurately encapsulated by two words|: "FUN" and "CHARMING'. Have a lot of fun things to do, and everything has a lot of quirkiness, be it the over the top fight scenes or the pocket racing minigame or the Cabaret Club thing that i never really paid a lot of attention to and definitely did NOT complete. There are also AV video stores in game as i have been told, but never came across.  The lock on system for the battle mechanics seriously can be infuriating at times, but the game makes up for it by letting you PICK A DUDE UP AND THEN JUMP WHILE TRYING TO CRUSH HIS HEAD ON THE PAVEMENT and letting you break dance your way out of a messy situation. 

As for story, it is decent if not better than that. It is complicated and feels a bit fragmented at times especially with new characters getting added every chapter almost. Guessing it has nostalgic value for people who know said characters from other Yakuza game but falls flat mostly for others, like me. Also, all bad characters you will beat up are BAD, until OP! NO THEY ARE NOT! They have a sad past you sadist POS so feel bad about beating the shit out of them after every boss battle.

Is Very Good game. I like. Even with the cutscenes and a crazy story which tries to do everything all at once, It is a very good game. Will Play further games in series. Will dies watching cutscenes half way through.

I'm having a lot of fun so far... though my game has randomly crashed twice which is frustrating. 146113294.review:
[h1]A prime example of how to make a story-driven game [/h1]

Definitely one of the best games I have played so far. The story is really deep and incredibly well done with a lot of drama and complex parts regarding the development of each character. The pacing of the story is also excellent, it never stops with filler content, it's always developing new drama and introducing new villains to the plot.
The most amazing part is how everything interconnects as you progress. No one is just a simple NPC. All of them have really deep reasons and complex connections to literally everything that is happening, and a lot of unexpected reveals also happen, which makes everything even more engaging. 
This game reminds me a lot of the Trails/Kiseki series where a lot of these deep character developments and interconnections happen. The difference here, at least within Yakuza 0, is that the pacing is faster.
The story in Yakuza 0 is amazing, and it's just the beginning of a very long saga and I can't wait to start playing the next game. I was afraid of starting playing this game before since there are 9 games to catch up, but after this game I noticed that once you start, you won't be able to stop playing.

Cinematography in Yakuza 0 is also excellent. Both the camera work and animations are really well done and it's clear that the series have a lot of influence from Japanese TV dramas. The graphics are really good during cutscenes, but the game definitely show it's age during gameplay since it's an old PS3 game with some limitations like having load transitions when entering stores, but still holds up really well. 
The PC Port is excellent. I ran the game at 1440p 60fps on a RTX 2060 Super using the maximum settings and it was perfect. Really stable frame rate, and zero issues regarding bugs or crashes.

The maps are also really dense and packed with things to do and sidestories. Yakuza 0 really shows the problem with most open worlds these days. A lot of recent open world titles are just big maps, but dead with almost no stores to enter or things to interact. Yakuza 0 does the opposite, the map is small but really dense and packed with content.
The side content available is really high quality and fun to play, especially the cabaret managing game. I was really impressed how much quality it has and how much customization options are available to improve the girls stats. The cabaret managing thing could be a standalone game by itself lol

My only nitpick about Yakuza 0 is the combat. It's not bad but it's not good either. It is a bit clunky and heavy to control, but it was never really an issue since the combat parts are easy and you can easily heal at any time.
There are only a few situations where the combat flaws really shows. If it was faster and had more evading or parrying mechanics, it would've been more fun to play.

Yakuza 0 is an amazing game and I feel like I should've started playing the series earlier. But at the same time, I think I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much if I starred playing it before. The series is definitely targeting an adult audience and there are some aspects about the story that we only understand after we become adults. A child or and adolescent would probably not appreciate this game's story as much as an adult, so I guess starting playing it now with a more mature mind was the right choice.
The story was so engaging that I didn't feel like stopping to do a lot of the side quests and minigames, so I focused mainly on the main story missions and it took about 26 hours to beat the game. I will still play the game a little bit more and do a few of the side content stuff before jumping on Kiwami 1.

It's definitely taking one spot in my Top10 games list. The story is incredible and very engaging that I couldn't stop playing until I finished the game. It's hard to keep writing about these games story deep games without spoiling anything. It's a game that you have to experience yourself to understand why there's so much love for the series and the overwhelmingly positive status on Steam is well deserved.

145957381.review:
I have to physically restrain myself from immediately launching the next game after finishing this one.

Even in my head this sounds pretentious but I'm going to include it anyway: Much like the game's protagonists themselves, Yakuza 0 tries absolutely everything that comes into the peripheral vision of the game's story path, and keeps a straight face from start to finish regardless of the execution. It manages to pull off a heavy and dramatic plot within the same hour of the goofy Japanese humour you've likely seen clips of online without falling apart at all.

The story and characters are enough to sell it, but then there's everything else on top of that.
This is a HUGE game and is a completionist's nightmare, but is best enjoyed by dipping into whatever side content looks fun and not worrying about finishing everything, playing this way absolutely still feels like a complete experience. It would not be tough to reach the credits of this game in half of the time that it took for me to beat it if you aren't sucked too much into the side content.

I would rather avoid spoiling anything about the game but the story really grabbed me and is a great place to come into the series with no knowledge.
Check this one out even if you aren't into brawler type games but remember that Real Yakuza Use A Gamepad.

145827926.review:
(Low hour count is because I ended up fully playing Yakuza 0 on my PS5 instead of on PC.)

     Man, what a game. Like many, I came to it because of all the memes from this game that were flying around in 2020-2021, but it has easily cemented itself as an all-time favorite for me. It manages to be both insanely bizarre and funny, while also being one of the few games to have genuinely moved me to tears. One minute you're singing karaoke in a bar or beating up Micheal Jackson's backup dancers, and the next you are witnessing one of the most well written and sad love stories I've seen in any game. 
     Plus on a mechanical level, its cool how so many of the games mechanics tie into the setting, that being Japan during the 1980's "bubble economy" era. You level up skills by literally investing in them, you get money for beating people in fights, etc. Plus this game being a prequel helps to make a lot of the big moments in Yakuza 1/Kiwami 1 hit a lot harder because we're now able to see the relationships between many of the characters before those events, and what led to them being where they are by the time Yakuza 1 starts.
