[quote=TalePlay][i] Check our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38352719/] Curator Page [/url] for short reviews. If you wish to get more gaming listings, news and reviews check our [url=https://www.youtube.com/@tale_play] Youtube [/url] channel as we release videos there often.[/i][/quote] 
 
[h2]In-depth[/h2] 
[h3] ⚔️ Gameplay & Exploration: [/h3]  
  
Yakuza 0 is a complex game with many activities that you can do. At its core, you have a fighting/beat'em up type of game with four fighting styles for Kiryu and Majima that you have to learn and master. Aside from that, you're going to encounter a lot of minigames, each feeling different, some requiring learning, and a lot of attention to detail has been put in place. Often, I've asked myself if I've switched games because not only do they look great, but they also feel great in the game.

From time to time, you'll have QTE moments that will demand quite a bit of effort from you. I've had moments like JCC, which is a Cat Fighting rock-paper-scissors game that you have to tap the key like a madman, and for days, I've had my right arm tired. The game takes itself seriously in the main story, but not as much in the side quests, where you'll have a lot of fun exploring the world.

The action takes place across two cities, Kamurocho and Sotenbori, where for the most part, it's defined for each character. Switching between Kiryu and Majima is done only via the main mission until the very last chapter and in free roam, where you can complete quests.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2911493250
 
[h3] 😄 Fun: [/h3]

One of the best 325 hours ever spent. This game is not boring. It will have so much content thrown at you that it might feel overwhelming. There are lots of things you can do, and you can do it at your own pace.
 
[h3] 🏞 Visuals & Presentation: [/h3]  
  
The game looks close to realism, and there's some great attention to detail in cutscenes. The characters look expressive and well-animated. The world is beautiful and believable. Play enough in Kamurocho and Sotenbori, and you'll get to feel like you're part of it.

The world is packed with things to see, attention to detail, and stunning light effects. Despite being a game that came out a few years ago, the game will continue to hold up for years to come.

Some cutscenes are not animated and there's some sort of inconsistency regarding that, but overall it's not a big issue once you understand how much work has been put into them.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3027200536
 
[h3] 🔊 Sound & Voice-Acting: [/h3]  
 
The game sounds great and is very well-voice-acted. Kiryu's voice is by far my favorite, but other characters also perform really well.

The world feels alive, with attention to detail in cutscenes, and even items falling out of the screen. It's a labor of love, and we can see that.
  
[h3] 📖 Story & Writing: [/h3]  
  
II jumped into this game with little expectation for the main story. I was proven wrong. The game has an incredible story that ties together so well until the end and stands strongly by itself and carries over into the sequels.

The tone of the main story is in stark contrast in comparison to the side quests, which define the protagonists and the characters in the world but can be ignored if you want to.

The story is about Kiryu, a Yakuza member who gets framed for a murder and has to figure out what's going on, resulting in losing his membership in the Yakuza family. Majima, an ex-Yakuza, resolves to do whatever it takes to rejoin the Yakuza family, although it's clear he has a softer heart than his appearance suggests.

The chapters are divided into 17 parts each, and for the most part, you'll play two chapters per character in the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3027200124
 
[h3] 🧵 Length & Difficulty: [/h3]  
  
It's a very lengthy game despite the fact that the world isn't that big. Because it's packed with content, you'll spend a lot of time completing it. You can complete the story in roughly 30 hours if you rush and focus only on it, but it's worth experiencing. There's a Legend difficulty to achieve 100% completion, which makes things tougher. However, the main challenge here lies in the minigames, where you have to learn and play them all to reach 100% completion.

[h3] ⭕️Verdict: [/h3]  
Yakuza 0 is a MUST-PLAY title, in my opinion. Its abundant and detailed minigames, goofy side stories, and incredibly dramatic main story make it one of the best games I've ever played. It's a game I'll always remember and gladly return to after a while because 325 hours in a game is plenty to take a break and focus on something new. The game might not be for everybody, but once you try it and it grips you, it's going to be hard to put down.

145665750.review:
I had tried playing Yakuza 0 twice before this excursion and bounced off both times. I’m not sure why the first time, but the second time I was completely unwilling to give it a chance. This past year I’ve been trying to go back to old games I bought and play them and I decided to give Yakuza 0 one more attempt. And I am so glad I gave the game a chance. 

The game has rocketed up to the very upper echelons of gaming for me. It’s truly an experience, almost a revelation. It is boundlessly cool. The story is enthralling. The characters are compelling. The gameplay is fun and engaging. It has it all in spades. And it’s such a unique experience. It’s more than the sum of its parts, too. Somehow this game, despite being such a chaotic morass, is just one of the most compelling experiences you’ll have in gaming. 

The story is a slow burn at the beginning, but when it finally hits, it hits hard. And while the game is known for being silly and out there, the story is anything but. The main story is a very serious crime drama that does not pull punches. It isn’t silly. It isn’t played for laughs. It’s hardboiled and utterly riveting. Go in expecting a yakuza Martin Scorcese story. 

The characters are all equally compelling. You will love them. You will hate them. You will cry for them. You will laugh with them. And the voice acting is fantastic. Everyone sells their performance hard and you will be completely engrossed in their performances. It’s always exciting to see them and to hear their interactions.

When I said the game was boundlessly cool, I meant it. There are moments in this game that are so damn cool that I couldn’t stop feeling giddy for a long time afterward. I’ve never played a game that had me feeling anywhere as cool as this one. And you’ll know what I mean when you get to those points. Hopefully you’ll have the same experience as I did.

It is when you get outside of the main story that the game’s tone diverges a lot. The side stories can be heartfelt, but a lot of the time they are outright silly and insane. It’s such a dichotomy, but they make it work. The side stories aren’t amazing. Certainly not anywhere near the scope of the main story, but they can be fun diversions and you get to see the sillier sides of the characters. They are endearing, even. And it is here where you’ll interact with the game’s many mini-games. 

The mini-games run the gamut: card games, pool, darts, bowling, karaoke, disco, pocket circuit racing, so on and so forth. Some are better than others and some are inconceivably cooler than you’d expect, like the disco (although I find it very hard). Still, when you are flowing with the disco and the music is thrumming while you are pulling off a dancing fever, it’s so much cooler than you’d think it would be. There are also some bigger mini-games, like the real estate and cabaret club management.

There’s a ton of side stuff and you’ll spend a lot of time with it, if you so choose. And you probably will because it can generally be quite fun and engaging. And dozens upon dozens of hours later you’ll wonder where all the time has gone.

So what can I say now at the end? I love Yakuza 0. I’m so glad I gave it another chance and discovered what a gem it is. It’s in my top games of all time now. And it has ignited a feverish desire in me to explore the rest of the series. I hope you can have the same experience as I have. Just give it a chance and let it work its magic. Don’t put it down until you are absolutely sure it is not for you. You may end up surprised.

145132351.review:
Yakuza 0 is a wonderful addition to the Yakuza series. The strong story and the many, often humorous, mini-games provide many hours of fun.
An attractive slip-on in the form of Yakuza 0.
This game takes place where it all begins, which is the great 80s.
Yakuza 0 is therefore a prequel which is an excellent choice for the first Yakuza.

The game also works great on a steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TRD5ppWpW7c

Since this game is about the Japanese mafia, fighting cannot be missed.
From drunken strangers to tattooed Yakuza bosses, almost no one escapes Kiryu and Majima's fists.
In the beginning you can get away with blindly approaching a brawl, but the final bosses in particular require some form of strategy.
During the game you have the opportunity to develop your character. This means that you can buy new moves that you can use in battles.
The fighting is quite repetitive, but nevertheless never really gets boring. The opponents are always different and that, together with the use of new moves, ensures that it remains fun.

Yakuza Zero is also a great game graphically. The character models of the main characters in the story look good, and the animations are also smooth. Unfortunately, this does not always apply to the NPCs in the area, but we just add this to the humorous part of the game.
Fortunately, it is not disturbing anywhere, since it belongs to the genre a bit. The world of Yakuza doesn't seem huge at first glance either, but the moment you start playing you realize that the world out there is crammed with details and ways to pass your time.
So in this case there is clearly a focus on quality of the world over quantity.

Yakuza 0 is not only a perfect entry point for new people, it is also the best game in the series.
Thanks to a wonderful 80s vibe, a sharp story and improved gameplay, the series is at its peak.
Yakuza 0 thus transcends the classification of 'simple prequel' and is elevated to an essential game.

145125734.review:
[i]Yakuza 0[/i] es un pico tanto de la saga como del videojuego en general que juega en la liga de secuelas/precuelas tan memorables como [i]Metal Gear Solid 2 (2001)[/i], [i] Red Dead Redemption 2 (2018)[/i] o [i]The Last of Us: Part II (2019)[/i].

Se ha dicho mucho que es un GTA japonés, pero esta comparación solo es acertada conceptualmente, ya que en ejecución no puede estar más lejos de los juegos de Rockstar. Y es que la saga de Toshihiro Nagoshi también es una sátira (aquí del país nipón), aunque ésta prioriza densidad de contenido por encima de tamaño del mundo. Recrea sólo el barrio rojo de Tokyo y el barrio comercial de Osaka, llenándolos de una cantidad de microdetalles y contenidos variados absurda. Merece la pena hacer todo lo secundario por lo divertido que es, los matices que aportan a los personajes, y las ventajas que desbloquean. Puedes hacer de todo, desde participar en concursos de baile o echar carreras de scalextric (personalización de coche incluida) hasta infiltrarte en una secta o poner a un pollo a dirigir tu sucursal inmobiliaria. Siempre te sorprende con su personalidad y forma de hacer.

La historia principal es la más centrada de toda la saga y habla principalmente de la especulación inmobiliaria y como la avaricia de unos pocos destroza la vida de muchos. La comedia y el drama tienen un encaje perfecto. Qué decir de los personajes. Las cinemáticas son algunas de las mejores que he visto en el medio, los combates contra jefes son increíbles. El gameplay es divertidísimo (Majima está rotísimo) y la música memorable, carne de playlist. 

Técnicamente es impecable, con un port que no me ha dado ningún problema. El aspecto visual y artístico es precioso, Kamurocho y Sotenbori nunca se habían visto tan bien. Pocas pegas se le pueden poner, es uno de los mejores RPG de acción que he jugado.

Nota: 98/100

144297020.review:
This game is just too much of everything, and I'm not sure I'll ever finish it. At the point of writing this, I was only on Chapter 8 with a reasonable attempt at side quest completion too.

If you know the good from the bad of proper Japanese cinema in the Yakuza genre, the main storyline is outstanding. SSS standard. It has serious dramatic depth and the voice acting is on point. As is the insane amount of in world "Japanese" lore. Whether its the era specific references and quirks, or just the universal cultural "things" that make Japan so unique. "0" is almost like a celebration of all things "fun" about the culture, with a very specific "arcade culture" flavour to it all.

The game is incredibly story heavy, and manages to mix humour and light silly fluff on the side in a very effective way that does not diminish or infect the main storyline. So you need to be mindful that this is not a game where  you can jump in for a quick session, and move on with the rest of your day. I made that mistake several times. There are a lot of surprise missions, both main or side quests, that suddenly spiral out of control with extended story content and combat, Before you know it 40 minutes has passed by before you have access to your next chance to safely save your progress... 40 minutes from triggering a simple "partial quest" activity that you were completely expecting to take only 5 minutes tops... and it still remains a "partial" completion of that quest. One occasion ended in a difficult boss fight where, if I had bailed, the last Save checkpoint would have had me re-fighting a swarm of underlings to get back to that boss fight (a fight that was not easy).

The game is good enough that those surprise time sinks don't feel like you are being cheated, but actually suck you in to want to see more, discover more. Very much a "one more mission" type of experience.

And all of that depth is somewhat ironic, because the open world precincts you have access to are really quite small, and sometimes heavily restricted when certain missions force you to "escape" something. It is a huge game experience in what is really a very small game world.

Even the silly side game and pseudo-JRPG grinding elements are actually fun and varied enough that they have value... unlike the many ultra grind mega open world AAA franchises out there today. Any silly side quest and collectable activities are entirely optional, even if some of them genuinely make the main story and mechanics easier to progress through. Therein lies the charm of this gameplay; you don't have to do the side stuff, but the game is successful at making you want to do it.

There are little quirks and bugs of course. It is a very good console port, but still a console port. So the fluidity and freedom of movement you expect at all times as a PC gamer makes some of the limitations in the ultra-arcadey combat mechanics feel little stiff. Still fun and challenging, and it genuinely requires combo/speed skills... but little things like that, even when freely exploring the streets will stand out as a "pfft... this is where the highest console standards are at...  peasants" moment for you. Still.. PC elitism aside, the game is so richly layered and well designed that you can accept those quirks as challenges rather than obstacles to the immersion.

Very unique experience that successfully combines so many different genre mechanics, but cannot really be compared to any other game out there.

I have played every single Yakuza game since the very first one which came out on the original PS2 in dubbed english. 
I still have that game too. I have bought every single yakuza game, its not for everyone, its a very niche market when it was first introduced to the west. When the 3rd game (Yakuza 3) came out, it was still a very niche market for this game in the west. but by the 4th, 5th instalment in the series, it was beginning to blow up in the western market. I love the funny quirky side quests, they're so Japanese, that only people who understand Japanese culture will understand. They have so many sub-cultures within a culture, its insane. 

Yakuza zero, is a prequel to Yakuza 1 or Yakuza Kiwami (Remake of Yakuza 1). 

It is based on the 1980's bubble era of Japan, in previous Yakuza games you played Kazama Kyriu, in later titles in the series you could play more unique characters, in this one, what made it so good, is that you can play as the Mad Dog himself, aka "Mad Dog" Majima San. In every previous Yakuza game, Majima was one of everyones favourate non-playable character, in this Yakuza Zero game, you get to see some scenes that tie into the first Yakuza game, which is nice. 

I would definately recommend to play this one first before jumping into Yakuza Kiwami (remake of Yakuza 1). 
Would i recommend this game?

Of course i would, if you want to experience the underbelly of Yakuza in the 1980's, you won't be disappointed.

144100459.review:
So folks, we're talking about a great gaming experience here.

Erase your concepts about Open World before trying this one out. Forget about GTA's, Sleeping Dogs and others. Instead, you'll face a semi-Open World (neighborhood ranging, basically) and loading to other spots.   

Well, this is my first Yakuza game, and I was a bit disappointed by the limited exploration, clunky M/K controls, and the excessive fighting focus. However, loads of things made me change my mind. 

- The story, acting, and music are flawless. You grow fond of all characters (Goro Majima, especially), friend or foe. 
- The fighting becomes kinda addicting once you upgrade your moves and get trinkets, weapons, etc.
- The minigames are ENDLESS and make you spend (or waste) a good time with them, including some SEGA classics. 
- You can also do unusual quests, like managing a Cabaret and a Real State Agency. 
- Side-quest stories are very engaging and can teach you some valuable lessons.

I guess those justify my almost 100h in this game. 
Oh, sir, I do recommend this game.

144062415.review:
I was a latecomer for Yakuza 0 back in August 2023, I finally got to finish the game after ~38 hours or so and I really have to say simply: THIS IS TRULY A VIDEO GAME.  It's a good crime drama, the combat is satisfying and every Heat attack moment packs that great OOMPH you want out of your big swings.  This game seriously has the best side quests I have ever seen in video games period, the soundtrack for this game is seriously amazing, and it also has an absurd amount of mini games and extra content to mess around with to the point that it made my brain turn to mush and shutdown after overload, seeing what it really means to be a top tier game not plagued by the things that bring down modern games of the current era.  

It is very hard to describe effectively into words how truly epic this game is, because others would pry and beg me into playing a Yakuza game in the past and I would decline because I just didn't know or understand any better.  After a few prods I finally took the leap and saw what it was all about and ended up getting so engrossed into all of the game's side quests for hours before realizing there was a main story I had been ignoring.  Now I'm turning into that person in a friend circle that is telling others how good the game is and that they too should join and play.  Yakuza gang is REAL.

144037290.review:
I (like many others) have been told repeatedly to dip my toes into the Yakuza world. I knew about the memes, I knew about the goofiness, I knew about the complex story lines, but what I didn't expect was my complete and total emotional investment in the game. I found myself becoming far too invested in the heartwarming backstories of NPCs and became genuinely disappointed when I lost a minigame.  Yakuza 0 does an excellent job drawing the player in and keeping the player invested with wild and outlandish combat and equally wild and outlandish writing. 

New to the Beat 'Em Up genre, I decided to set the difficulty to Easy until I was able to sort out the gameplay. To my surprise, the combat is extremely intuitive yet provides challenging combos and QTEs for more experienced players. I ended up switching the difficulty to Normal around 1/3rd of the way through the run and was satisfied with the difficulty of enemies and bosses. 

I would highly recommend this game to anyone and I genuinely hope that this review urges people on the fence to give this series a go.

143695403.review:
WARNING
There is a common bug that ruins your equipment in this game. Sometimes when you save it will not display the "save complete" message. This will turn your equipment into food items. You can fix this by saving until you see that message. Besides that, no bugs that I have encountered

I kinda just paragraphed off in this. So enjoy a mostly unorganized review :)

The real estate was pretty fun. Nice and simple money goes up sorta dealio. The fights were fun, and unlocking your styles abilities was great. But my problem with it is that it seems optional but if you treat it as that, you miss out on a lot of the games combat abilities. While yes you can use a shrine ability to unlock the extra abilities, you simply will not be able to afford them. I liked how everything in this game felt optional, and this took a bit of that away. Granted, it was fun and all (Besides the last area, it got really slow), but it was portrayed as optional, when it is technically, but not really. Besides that, the real estate was a like 8/10 game within this game. If you don't have a spare 10 hours for this segment of the game, just cheat to get the unlocks

I did not bother with the Cabaret club. I wanted to just play the story and well...

The game punishes you for not doing the business mini game. Like heavily punishes you. I was playing on Hard and everything was dying so easily as Kiryu. Once I was as Majima though, it got much tougher. The character progression is tied to the businesses. I think this is awful and frankly the biggest problem with Yakuza 0. It seems optional, but it isn't. Skip on the businesses and you miss out on most of the abilities, a secret style, and a ton of Completion Points. With Kiryu, the combat was fun and balanced because I had sunk the 10 or so hours in real estate. With Majima, the combat was much more basic and mind numbing. Enemies barely took damage. I will admit, I cheated in the secret style for Majima just to see what it was like, and it sucked. Super low damage, heat gain, and only 2 heat actions. I am glad I skipped his minigame because putting all that effort in for that would have made me quit.

I had liked the combat at first, but it overstayed its welcome. I enjoy simplier combat systems like this. Not everything needs to be Devil May Cry. But my problem with it was the slow progression mixed with how long the game is. Everything felt so dragged out. At the end, I only enjoyed Kiryu's gameplay but not really Majima's at all. All because of the messed up progression system. In smaller burst, the combat is fun. I think 60 hours was a bit too long for it though.

Music was sick. I never really liked dubstep, but gosh the battle themes just do it right. I have not much else to say, it just be good music.

I liked the open world a lot in this game because it was compact. There is very minimal mindless walking in it. A lot of larger open world games have emptiness problems, but by staying small, Yakuza 0 ends up feeling much bigger and real.

Story was great and the main reason I played near the end. It made me tear up, get pissed, and the whole 9 yards. It is a very "small deal spirals out of control" story which was nice. The end kinda confused me though. 
[spoiler] Also I had people tell me this was how Majima "breaks" but he never does? He kinda just chooses to live crazier at the end which was pretty unsatisfying. [/spoiler]

Overall, it is a good game, but one with a major flaw. I feel a game half this length would have been much better. It took me 4 months to beat, and has a lot of bang for your buck. 8/10

143604158.review:
This game is honestly one of the greatest I have ever played. I first played it on Xbox via gamepass and nearly completed it. It was the game I needed in a difficult (and still in many ways an on going) part of my life. 

The two protagonists are some of the greatest and most interesting characters, combine that with the amazing combat of the game (love the heat actions) and you got yourself a good game.

Now combine that with great music, great bosses, a great story, and an almost endless amount of side content and you've got what I say is a practically perfect game in my eyes. And maybe in yours too.

The game taught me so much of what it means to persevere, protect others, and so much more (yakuza 5 reference not intended?!11!?1?!) through both its more-serious main story and often comedic-till-the-end side-stories.

Oh and if you ever get bored along the way the mods for this game is amazing. 

Yakuza 0 and its subsequent games are the reason I love this franchise, and this game is a masterpiece that introduced me well into it all. 

Bonus: The game is basically Japan simulator or something (I don't know I've never been to Japan).

143406111.review:
Where to even begin? This game is great. The story, the characters, the combat, the city life... everything! So much happens so quickly and you can't help but feel hooked. The story of Kazuma Kiryu's life in 'the family' is such a time and a half. It's filled with excitement, camaraderie, tragedy, heartache, highs and lows, everything you could want for a yakuza story. Without divulging too much, Goro Majima's story gives an equal amount of thrill and sadness and both people make for such great protagonists. The combat... oh man, the combat! It's violent it's brutal, and nobody dies! Or at least maybe they do, but uh... Kiryu never kills anyone. Never. There are Heat Actions to perform and there are a LOT of them just waiting for you to witness. Upgrades, upgrades, and more! The combat is satisfying and you'll be earning money in the process, so beat 'em up!
Substories! There's a LOT and they're all their own little adventure. Some are... questionable but there's always a goal to reach for each of these little breaks from the main game. It's these substories you can do that really do help the city feel alive and of course it helps the protagonist feel more human and allows you understand their personality better through the actions and dialogue in all of these.
Minigames! There's a handful! Some are not the faint of heart if you're a completionist and an achievement hunter. So if you're ready to take on Japanese Mahjong from the ground-up, dance the night away, bowl some strikes, bet on wrestling, and race some snazzy toy cars, then good luck!

143181830.review:
(Play time inflated due to playing between calls at work)

Overall, I found this to be a pretty enjoyable entry in the series. It's very interesting to see the origin stories of two of the most iconic characters, and it provides a lot of background that makes you appreciate the rest of the games in a new way.

The battle system is as hilariously unbalanced as always, but you have multiple ways of becoming an all-star fighter with both characters. In this game, money is used for everything up to and including leveling up, so you'll find you need more cash than you ever have in any other game to date. While this was an interesting premise, I found that I had to level up in fits and starts, and didn't really get a steady advancement of skills. As soon as both characters get their businesses going, you have good seed money, but even then you can't really max them out easily unless you use an exploit exclusive to Kiryu and then pass the benefits to Majima near the end of the game.

Anyway, even if this game doesn't really do much new for battles, I found the story very enjoyable, and I liked seeing how the characters change. You see many, many people in this game that have been in the other titles. Sometimes they just appear as cameos, other times as significant story characters.

I find it very remarkable that as the game went on, I became increasingly more interested in Majima's side of the story than Kiryu's. Kiryu's isn't bad by any means, it's just that you kind of already know what you're going to get with him: Thousand yard stares and punching people to advance the plot. Majima's content fills in a lot of gaps in his character, and overall I found his changes to be the more compelling of the two.

All in all, a pretty good entry in the series, and really great for filling in the plot. Recommended.

143180251.review: Where else can you go from being a gritty, feared Yakuza enforcer to helping a shy dominatrix in the space of minutes? Only in Yakuza 0! This game is like a sushi roll filled with high stakes crime drama, then topped with a generous sprinkle of ridiculous side quests. One minute, you're smashing faces with bicycles, the next, you're busting out disco moves that'd make John Travolta jealous! It's a seamless blend of 'OH MY GOD' and 'WTF?!' moments that never feels out of place. The 1980s Japan setting is richly detailed, pulling you in with its neon-lit charm and keeping you there with its engaging storytelling. Yakuza 0 is like a roundhouse kick to the face - unexpected, slightly ridiculous, but you're left wanting more.

143010004.review:
Yakuza 0, What a game. At the time of writing this review I still haven't finished the main story and I am only on Chapter 7, probably around the mid point of the game. And yet I've clocked in about 60 hours already in to the game.

Now you might be asking, surely the game isn't that long that it's 60 hours of slow paced story just to get to the middle of the game. Short answer: No. No it is not. The long answer is a little more complicated. This game does an amazing job at giving the player options in the open world. There is plenty of side content in a smaller but much more detailed and filled in open world segment. The game walks a perfect balance between content and how the open world is presented.

What makes this game so unique is that it features two protagonists, two main characters that remain fundamental to the whole Yakuza story even after 0. This is where I am most amazed at this game because they made both protagonists equally as interesting which we all know is an incredibly difficult feat to do. They're nuanced, they have character, they're fully fleshed out and most important of all, they both have some of the most badass moments I have seen in any game topping the set pieces of games like Uncharted.

The combat is some of the best combat I have ever played and seen in a game. It is fluid, smooth, exciting and brutal. The controls are intuitive and making combos is easy and engaging. The skill tree is expansive and detailed leaving for some great growth along the way as you make the journey through the game's story and open world.

And yes, there is an "achievement list" or completion list as they call it in the game to keep track of all the side content in the game which you get rewarded with CP = completion points that you can use at the Shrine or Temple in the game to permanently upgrade your character or businesses. I forgot to mention, you can become the CEO of a Real Estate Company or a Manager at a Cabaret Club which both have their own mini-games.

TLDR: This game is fun, exciting and amazing all the way through with great story pacing and an engaging gameplay loop. Do yourself a favour and at least try the game out when it goes on sale!

142858254.review: When I first leaned about the Yakuza series, I was blown away by how many games were in the series, but as I began to play the first game, as I thought it was good to start at the very beginning, I could see why. The games are addicting and the stories are absolutely amazing. I felt like a was watching a TV show throughout the whole thing. Sometimes the cutscenes were in fact long enough to be a TV episode. I think this game wins the best story from me, due to how amazing it is. For the gameplay, the combat is great and it managed to be flashy while still intresting, difficult and not just button marshy. This is also one of the most random games I have ever played. In the first hour you go from beating someone up in an alley to singing kareoke to getting accused for a murder, which is surprising how a murder can happen in the yakuza world since people can be stabbed like 15 times in the chest and still be up and fighting, speaking of, the special moves when fighting were amazing and comically funny. The amount of things to do aside from the story are also crazy. You can be calling babes on the phone, then go bowling, then hit up the batting cages, then gamble all of your money away, then make some back at the cabaret club, then invest in real estate and finish the day with some fun arcade games. The hundredish side missions were also very fun and super intresting, yet I skipped a lot of them as about a third were tied to the cabernet club and real estate side games. Overall, Yakzua 0 was an amazing game with one of the best stories I have ever seen and so much variation that sometimes you will forget that you are playing a Japanese crime drama. The game is not for people who cannot get invested however, as it is very long and some of the cutscenes take forever to get through, but it is all worth it in the end.

142846053.review:
This is one of the best games i've ever played

I loved the character development, and don't think there's any other game that made me absolutely hate its antagonists/villains at first but grew to respect and even love them by the end of the game.

Music is amazing and gets you pumped up when in combat. But even out of combat, the soundtrack is great.

Cutscenes make you feel like you're watching a film. I played in ultra and enjoyed the graphics - every pore and scar on a character's face makes them so much more alive. The nuance of expressions and body language is captured well too.

The main story is so good that close to midgame I started ignoring minigames and sidequests, and all the other stuff because I was too invested in the main story. The cliffhangers after each chapter, twists and turns - some expected, some not so much. It's really a ride.

With all that said, I don't think it's for everyone. If you can't stand long cutscenes (and I mean VERY long) with a lot of talking, aren't a fan of the beat em up/brawler combat style which can get tedious after a while (though the game allows you to literally throw away money to avoid combat later on - which I did), or don't usually play games with subtitles on, this game might not be great. 

wonderful game, i really liked it

It was okay, I recommend you get it on sale and you won't be disappointed. 

I bought the 0-6 pack on steam sale for about $55 CDN.

Where the game falls short for me is in the writing style, you have this build up to the big scenes only to have the momentum stopped like slamming on the brakes at 100 miles an hour. One example is near the end of ch4 the game really picks up but the start of ch5 the brakes are slammed hard, sending the story out the front windshield and causing it to crawl and then limp along for a while.

Characters were also not that interesting, having to see literally the same character personality across pretty much all the villains, I just start to get annoyed seeing the the same acting style as yakuza characters all act and scream the same way, it was really annoying. The main characters weren't all that fleshed out either and as someone who has yet to play Yakuza 1-6 I found myself not really caring about these characters. It's obvious this game expects you to play the other games cause I don't see too many new players caring much about these characters.

Gameplay was fine but a bit repetitive.

Not much variety in maps, you just run back and forth through the same two maps for the most part.

Music was decent.

Graphics were decent.

Overall, I would say this game is decent but not great, don't come in expecting something high budget like Star Field and you should have some fun but if you're gonna finish it, you gotta be patient and suffer through the boring parts. 

Lot's of ups and downs with this one for me, but not the worst game I've played. Also, I did play Like A Dragon (Yakuza 7) before I played this and in comparison, Like A Dragon is the better game between these two anyway.

142415332.review:
[b]Yakuza 0[/b] was my first game in the series since I decided to play chronologically, and [b]Like a Dragon: Ishin![/b] was not ported to PC yet. 

Initially, I had a hard time with this game because I did not enjoy combat. I mean, it's not terrible, it just got old pretty quickly for me. I even thought of dropping the game for good because of this. But the level of detail of everything, amazing sidequests, characters, and surprisingly dramatic, emotional story with many twists and turns dragged me through the entire game. I couldn't stop playing and spent several evenings in a row just to see what would happen next. Yeah, there're some anime bullshit moments throughout the main story, the level of absurd in certain sidequests might not be everyone's cup of tea, and some characters, including the main protagonist Kazuma Kiryu, act and look like they came straight from [b]JoJo's Bizarre Adventure[/b]. Still, overall I was impressed, and I will play through the entire series now.

So yeah, in short, if you like a quite primitive beat 'em up combat, intriguing story, painfully detailed minigames, and everything Japanese, then definitely give this game a go.

141836455.review:
It's pretty hard to say something about this game that hasn't been said already. A lot of the non-joking top rated reviews already do a pretty good job on selling you on the game.
Even if you have no plans to play the rest of Ryu Ga Gotoku studio's titles, Yakuza 0 is a must play for almost anyone with a system that can play it. Its default price being as cheap as it is makes it even more of a steal.

Fittingly for something that's the first in the series chronologically, Y0 embodies almost everything that makes the series great. Hubs that, instead of being massive open worlds with nothing in them, are several city blocks that you'll come to know like the back of your hand in the best way. Combat that, this time around, has 6 fighting styles (plus 2 bonus ones) that are super fun to experiment with even if they're not balanced in the slightest (though literally no RGG game is balanced). Tons of minigames and side modes to try, from original Karaoke songs sung by the characters' VAs, to what may be why you get into Riichi Mahjong or Shogi. A soundtrack that's 88 tracks long, with contributions from at least 16 composers. Tons of substories that tell some of the most ridiculous and hilarious tales in the series yet. And, of course, a dramatic main story that unexpectedly pulls you in after hearing about how goofy the game is with amazing characters and voice acting.

I will say the game isn't the perfect instalment as it falls in places that other Yakuza games don't as much:
-Catfight club is god awful and can actively hurt you with how much it encourages you to mash.
-Collosseum is extremely grindy for no real reason, Yakuza 5 is unfortunately similar. Kiwami, which was developed after 0, isn't as bad with this though.
-Telephone Club is badly thought out with unskippable cutscenes every time you go through it and needing to go through it at least 7 times to unlock its substories (and you will be going through it quite a bit more than 7 times), which are needed to face the game's fun bonus boss.
-Upgrades have weird progression. In past games you are rewarded in exp for fighting and doing substories, upgrades coming gradually throughout your playthrough. In 0, because of upgrades happening through money, you go from the stage where you get upgrades from fighting and selling plates, to when you unlock the businesses and get better profits (even then not that much with Majima), to when you're able to exploit mr shakedown and get basically unlimited money for every upgrade at once. Even then Majima can't do this and must wait until Kiryu can transfer enough money to him which is kinda late in the game.

141623564.review:
This game is quite fantastic. The combat is solid, simple, but enjoyable. It has a solid foundation of beat-em-up fighting mechanics, plenty of visual candy in its over-the-top finisher cut scenes. Some additional depth is added so its not a completely brain-dead button masher, one needs to properly manage their character's finisher energy, and needs to utilize defensive options well on the higher difficulties to not burn through all their heath items. Overall its not a difficult game mechanically, even on the hardest difficulty.

The setting is where this game truly shines. Set in a fictitious red light district of Tokyo in the early 80s, its a fascinating combination of grime and glitz. Seedy characters in leisure suits get curbstomped next to piles of garbage. You befriend convenience store workers, cabaret workers, arcade workers, fishermen, sushi chefs, and the odd homeless person. There's no shortage of serious, silly, and raunchy in Kamurocho.

Combined with all the side activities engrossing everything from baseball, to bowling, to telephone dating, to betting on cat fights there's just so much to enjoy about this game. It tries to do alot, and it does it mostly well.

Easily one of my favorite games of all time.

141553576.review:
A Mesmerizing Journey Through the Heart of Japan's Underworld: Yakuza 0

Rating: ★★★★★

Yakuza 0 is an absolute masterpiece that immerses players in a captivating world of crime, honor, and redemption. Developed by Ryu Ga Gotoku Studio, this prequel to the acclaimed Yakuza series delivers an unforgettable experience that flawlessly blends an engaging narrative, rich characters, and a vibrant open-world setting. From its enthralling storyline to its diverse gameplay mechanics, Yakuza 0 sets a new standard for open-world action-adventure games.

One of the standout features of Yakuza 0 is its intricate and compelling narrative. Set in the neon-lit streets of 1980s Japan, players assume the roles of two protagonists, Kazuma Kiryu and Goro Majima. The intertwining stories of these two characters are masterfully crafted, offering a deep exploration of their personal struggles, ambitions, and the complexities of the Yakuza lifestyle. The plot is filled with unexpected twists, dramatic moments, and an abundance of well-written dialogue that keeps you hooked from start to finish.

The attention to detail in Yakuza 0 is exceptional, both in terms of its storytelling and the meticulously designed world. The game flawlessly captures the essence of Japan during the bubble economy era, showcasing bustling city streets, authentic landmarks, and vibrant districts teeming with life. The level of immersion is unparalleled, and you'll find yourself engrossed in the bustling nightlife, engaging in side activities like karaoke, bowling, gambling, and even managing a cabaret club. Each corner of the city is filled with secrets to discover, adding layers of depth to the overall experience.

Combat in Yakuza 0 is a perfect blend of accessibility and complexity. Players can unleash a variety of devastating attacks, string together combos, and utilize character-specific heat actions to dispatch enemies in stylish and brutal fashion. The combat system is intuitive, allowing both newcomers and series veterans to feel right at home. Moreover, the upgrade system provides a sense of progression, enabling players to unlock new abilities and fighting styles, ensuring combat never feels monotonous.

Beyond combat, the game offers a plethora of side missions and mini-games that further enrich the gameplay experience. From helping citizens in need to engaging in quirky tasks like managing a real estate business or becoming a disco dance champion, the side activities provide a welcome break from the main storyline, offering hours of additional content and rewarding encounters with a cast of memorable and quirky characters.

Graphically, Yakuza 0 shines with its attention to detail, realistic character models, and stunning recreations of 1980s Japan. The art style captures the essence of the era, while the excellent voice acting, coupled with a well-crafted soundtrack, brings the world to life. Whether it's the energetic pop tunes of the karaoke bar or the melancholic melodies that accompany emotional moments, the audio design excels at setting the mood.

In conclusion, Yakuza 0 is an absolute triumph that seamlessly blends a gripping narrative, immersive open-world gameplay, and a rich tapestry of characters. Its flawless execution, attention to detail, and commitment to delivering a captivating experience make it an essential entry in the Yakuza series and a standout title in the open-world genre. Whether you're a fan of the series or new to the Yakuza universe, Yakuza 0 is an absolute must-play that will leave an indelible mark on your gaming journey.

By the time that I've written this review, I have put in 45 hours of playtime into Yakuza 0. At that point, I would have reached Chapter 7... out of 17 chapters (Lord help me). Surprisingly, there is so much in-game content to keep me playing for so long, despite this game's overworld map being as large as two city blocks. In fact, I was so enamored with unethical real estate speculation and collecting both 2D and 3D girls that I completely forgot I was watching the Godfather during Japan's asset price bubble. I guess it's not really a modern Sega if it doesn't have at least 250 hours of side content and in-depth trivia nuggets about every single item. But I suppose this sort of meticulousness something I've really grown to love about Yakuza 0.

I'd recommend it to anyone with good time management skills, and also as a perfect starting point to the Yakuza/Like a Dragon series.

While most describe this as a 20-hour game, that's just if you beeline from plot point to plot point. In reality this is up there with the 40+ hour games, if you allow yourself to become sidetracked by the countless side activities this game offers, all of them very well made and rewarding to play. And while this IS a prequel, I would say that this can be experienced as a one-off thing, so don't feel pressured into continuing the plot with the 7 other games in this series.

My only gripe is that in the later fights, enemies with guns come into play. And when you get shot, you spend a minute just flailing around and mashing A to get up. And then there are three to five enemies with guns (on top of the rest of the enemies in encounters). I don't think I've yet to encounter a game where the player attacks in melee and has fun encountering enemies with guns.
